description.en: Represents a collection of people organized together into a community or other social, commercial or political structure. The group has some common purpose or reason for existence which goes beyond the set of people belonging to it and can act as an Agent. Organizations are often decomposable into hierarchical structures.
Description of the Organisation.
Information such as mail address, telephone, ... that can be used to contact the Organisation.
Other name for the Organisation.
Name that is the preferred designation of the Organisation.
Type of Organisation.
An Organisation that is legally registered.
The legal name of the Registered Organisation.
The registration is a fundamental relationship between a legal entity and the authority with which it is registered and that confers legal status upon it.
The accessibility characteristics of an entity used by passengers such as a Stop Place.
A grouping of Stop Places which will be commonly referenced for a specific purpose (stops inside an airport, main stops of a city, etc.).
Stop Place that is a member of the Group of Stop Places.
Transport mode of the Group of Stop Places.
An identified storey (ground, first, basement, mezzanine, etc) within an interchange building or Site on which Site Components reside.
Parameters and properties to be used when processing and presenting data in a country or region (time zone, language, etc.).
A company providing public transport services.
Postal address of the Operator.
Reference to the Country.
Primary Transport Mode of the Operator.
The allocation of a Scheduled Stop Point  to a Stop Place.
Reference to a Quay within the Stop Place to which the Scheduled Stop Point is assigned.
A 0-dimensional node of the Network used for the spatial description of the Network. Points may be located by a Location in a given Locating System.
Location of the Point.
Name of the Point.
Arbitrary alternative identifier for the Point.
Projection for the Point.
A type of Place to or through which passengers may wish to navigate as part of their journey and which is modelled in detail by journey planners.
Stop Place that serves the Point of Interest.
Defines a uniform set of values to control appearances of an element (on a map, a schematic map, a paper or screen description, etc.).
A  place such as a platform, bus stop, stance or quay side where passengers have access to public transport vehicles, taxi, cars or other means of transportation.
Bearing of street relative to Quay in degrees (absolute bearing of front part of Vehicle when stopped at Quay).
Label of the Quay.
Level of the Quay.
Other transport modes of the Quay.
Asset code used to identify the Quay.
Code use to identify Quay to the public.
Sub Quay.

usage.en: A Quay may contain other sub Quays. A child Quay shall be physically contained within its parent Quay. This allows one to represent composite platforms with two or more sides or named sections. One can thus journey plan to any level of detail.

description.en: Classification of the Quay.
Submode of the Quay.
Tariff zone of the Quay.
The main transport mode of the Stop Place.
A Point where passengers can board or alight from vehicles.
Description of the Scheduled Stop Point.
Location of the Scheduled Stop Point.
Name of the Scheduled Stop Point.
Presentation values to use when rendering the Stop Point such as a colour and font.
Alternative identifier of the Scheduled Stop Point.

usage.en: Can be used to associate with legacy systems.

description.en: Public code of the Scheduled Stop Point.
Short name of the Scheduled Stop Point.
Type of Stop Place.
Tariff Zones to which the Scheduled Stop Point belongs.
Timing status of the Scheduled Stop Point.
Link between an ordered pair of Scheduled Stop Points.
Distance of the Service Link.
Linestring that specifies the Service Link.
Name of the Service Link.
A Stop Place represents a station, stop, port, airport or any physical point of access to the transport network.
Indicates whether the Stop Place is covered or outdoors.
Access modes by which the Stop Place may be accessed.
The overall accessibility characteristics of the Stop Place.
Alternative name for the Stop Place.

usage.en: Used for Stops that have multiple aliases.

description.en: Indicates whether the Stop Place is a border crossing.
Centre Point of the Stop Place.
The Quays contained in the Stop Place, that is platforms, jetties, bays, taxi ranks, and other points of physical access to Vehicles.
Name of nearest cross road or crossing street on which the Stop Place is and which can be used to locate the Stop Place.

usage.en: Mainly relevant for bus modes, where the cross road may provide necessary context to describe the stop to a user.

description.en: Entrance of the Stop Place.
Stop Place that is the main terminus of the Topographic Place.
Indicates whether the Stop Place is within a gated area.
Default image for the Stop Place.
Topographic Place in the Stop Place.
Name of a nearby Landmark.
Levels for the Stop Place.
Indicates how well the Stop Place is lit.
Locale setting the time zone, default language, etc., for the Stop Place.
Country where the Stop Place is located.
Reference to the Operator of the Stop Place.
The other Transport Mode available at the Stop Place.
Refers to the parent Stop Place of the Stop Place.
Categorisation of Place.
Polygon associated with the Stop Place.
A postal address to which mail can be sent.
Code used to identify a Stop Place to the public as an alternative to a name.
Address of a numbered building on a named road.
Point of Interest that is served by the Stop Place.
Topographic Place which the Stop Place serves.
The type of Stop Place.
Type of expected Interchange at the Stop Place.
Submode associated with the Stop Place.
Tariff zone associated with the Stop Place.
The main transport mode of the Stop Place.
URL with information of the Stop Place.
Default relative weighting to be used for the Stop Place.
Physical entrance or exit to/from a Stop Place for a passenger.
Indicates whether there is a dropped curb outside the Entrance.
Type of Entrance.
Height of the Entrance.
Indicates whether the Entrance can be used for entry to the Stop Place.
Indicates whether the Entrance can be used for exit from the Stop Place.
Indicates whether the Entrance opens externally.
Label of the Entrance.
Level of the Entrance.
Other transport mode of the Entrance.
Public code for the Stop Place Entrance.
Submode of the Entrance.
Tariff zone of the Entrance.
The main transport mode of the Stop Place.
Width of the Entrance.
Each Point inJourney Pattern specifies the visit of a Service to a specific Scheduled Stop Point in a particular order within the pattern.
Booking Arrangement for stop if different from those for Service Journey.
Indicates whether Destination Display changes at this point.
Destination Display values to show at this point.
Flexible properties of the Point.
Indicates whetherthe Stop Point may be used for alighting.
Indicates whetherthe Stop Point may be used for boarding.
Notice for the Stop Point in Journey Pattern.
Next Service Link after Stop Point in Journey Pattern visit.

usage.en:
This attribute shall only be used if multiple Service Links 
are available between two consecutive Scheduled Stop Points. Otherwise, the sequence of Stop Points in Journey Pattern to the Scheduled Stop Point is sufficient and remains the main way of describing the stop sequence.

description.en: Order of Stop Point in Journey Pattern within Journey Pattern.
Method to request stop in this particular service pattern; if none specified, as per stop.
Indicates whether stop is a request for stop in this journey. Default if false.
Nature of use of stop. Default is "access".
A Zone used to define a zonal fare structure.
A geographical settlement which provides topographical context when searching for or presenting travel information, for example as the origin or destination of a trip.
Stop Place contained in the Topographic Place.
Topographic Place for which the Stop Place is the main terminus.
Stop Place that serves the Topographic Place.

A 0-dimensional geometric object tjat represents a single location in coordinate space. A Point has an x-coordinate value, a y-coordinate value. If called for by the associated Spatial Reference System, it may also have coordinate values for z and m. The boundary of a Point is the empty set.
Location of the Point.
Name of the Point.
Arbitrary alternative identifier for the Point.
Projection for the Point.
A planar Surface defined by 1 exterior boundary and 0 or more interior boundaries. Each interior boundary defines a hole in the Polygon.

The Identifier class represents any identifier issued by any authority, whether a government agency or not. It captures the identifier itself, the type of identifier, and details of the issuing authority, the date on which the identifier was issued.
The URI of the issuing authority.
The date on which the Identifier was assigned.
The value of this property is the Identifier itself.
The name of the agency responsible for issuing the Identifier.
A spatial object that in a human-readable way identifies a fixed location of a property.
Form and position characteristics of an Object.
Geometry expressed in GML-format.
Geometry expressed in WKT-format.
Unit as defined by a standardising organisation.
Designation of a quantity.
Designation of the quantity of a certain characteristic of an Object.
Standarised unit in which the value is expressed.
The unit in which the value is expressed.
Number used to express the quantity of the characteristic.
